School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Jiangsu University of Science and Technology Zhenjiang Jiangsu 212003 China 1 These authors equally contributed to this work. Photothermal hybrids composed of nanocarbon and metal species are promising in solar-driven photothermal conversion and later application of water purification. Herein, the photothermal hybrid with surface-polarized carbon nanotube (CNT) twined oxygen vacancy-engineered cuprous oxides was constructed. The surface polar oxygen and nitrogen moieties were introduced onto the CNT, enriching the surface polarity of the nanocarbon, which further twined the in-situ generated oxygen vacancy-engineered cuprous oxides. The constructed catalyst was endowed with abundant Cu(I) reactive sites and oxygen vacancy, providing the efficient trapping effect and enough exposed active sites to trigger improved peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation. In addition, the obtained catalyst affords superior photothermal conversion efficiency, thereby showcasing the great potential in solar-driven water purification. Therefore, the catalyst shows excellent bisphenol A (BPA) degradation performance with a reaction rate constant of 0.47 min-1, and activation energy (Ea=9.38 kJ·mol-1).. The reaction mechanism study indicates the main contribution of singlet oxygen and superoxide radicals in the BPA degradation. More importantly, the obtained catalyst affords the excellent total organic carbon (TOC) removal ability for mixed contaminants, higher than that of single contaminant removal, which shows great potential for practical complicated wastewater purification. Finally, the obtained photothermal hybrids were anchored onto the tailored sponge through a hydrogel tethering strategy, which acts as a monolith evaporator to enable cleanwater regeneration and contaminant degradation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal hybrid Cuprous oxides Oxygen vacancy Pollutants degradation Monolith evaporator Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid development of industry has caused gradually serious water pollution, which threatens the health of human society and makes the water resource shortage serious [1,2]. In particular, water body containing organic contaminants such as BPA is widely used in plastics in many industrial productions, and corresponding evidence has demonstrated that BPA has been released from plastic containers into water bodies, which possibly enters into human bodies resulting in failing in efficient metabolism [3,4]. In addition to BPA, the massive use of antibiotics globally each year inevitably leads to their introduction into the real world, such as tetracycline, oxytetracycline, norfloxacin, etc., which has a great impact on the environment [5]. Correspondingly, the removal of pollutants from water and the regeneration of clean water have become hot issues that need to be solved urgently. In recent years, the advanced oxidation process (AOP) has received increasing attention and was gradually applied in the treatment of water pollution especially for degrading pollutants in water [6–8]. AOPs can degrade pollutants in water through various strong oxidative radicals, note that PMS affords huge advantages in pollutant degradation because the asymmetric structure of PMS can be easily decomposed into various radical species such as sulfate radical (SO4 · -), Hydroxyl radical (·OH), superoxide radicals (·O2 -) and singlet oxygen (1O2), resulting in high degradation rate and mineralization efficiency for difficult-to-degrade pollutants. In particular,·OH and SO4 · - have strong oxidative potential, wherein the standard redox potential ( EHO= 3.1 eV) of SO4 · - is higher than that of hydroxyl radical ( EHO= 1.8–2.7 eV). Therefore, the sulfate radical involving AOP is considered a feasible technology to replace the traditional Fe2+/H2O2 system [9,10]. Note that ·O2 - and 1O2 generally afford longer half-life periods and stronger stability compared to ·OH and SO4 · - especially in the real water world containing various quenching substances, which against the rapid quenching effect of radicals. Therefore, the promoted generation of ·O2 - and 1O2 is beneficial to wastewater treatment in the real world. The controlled generation of these oxidative active species needs to be studied to cater to the practical application process. In general, PMS molecule has the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals with low energies and are more easily activated by transition metal catalysts such as Co, Mn, Fe, Co, and Cu and their derivative [11,12]. by inducing the electrons to transfer from PMS molecules to metal sites. Through constructing a site-specific catalytic center, the O-O or O-S cleavage of PMS can be oriented and controlled to generate expected active species [13–15]. Although cobalt-based materials have excellent performance for PMS activation, the easy leaching of the high toxicity of cobalt from catalysts would possibly lead to secondary pollution and poor practical application potential. In contrast, copper-based catalyst affords low toxicity, high stability, high activation efficiency, and low leaching rate, which is promising in later applications [16–18]. However, the low valence abundance of copper species makes it have worse redox in the reaction process. Correspondingly, the modulation of PMS activation to trigger more generation of ·O2 - and 1O2 is challenged. Previous studies reveal that the compositing metal species with carbon-based materials afford a large advantage in PMS activation. In particular, the improvement of copper-based catalyst anchored onto nanocarbon induced the improved electron transfer is possibly beneficial for controlling the O-O cleavage of PMS [19,20]. Various carbon nanomaterials, such as graphene, activated carbon, nanodiamonds, and CNTs, have received extensive attention in recent years [21,22]. CNTs, featuring a large surface area, high electrical conductivity, and abundant free electron structure defects on their surfaces, have been demonstrated to be active for PMS activation and radical generation [23–25]. However, CNTs have limited ability for PMS activation in a specific pH range, showcasing poor flexibility in controlling the generation of various active radicals [26,27]. Heteroatom doping can adjust the charge density of carbon-based materials, causing a higher defect level and surface polarity [28,29]. Some edge and corner sites composed of ending moieties possibly act as active centers [30]. Specifically, the negatively charged nitrogen graphite atoms can positively polarize the neighboring carbon atoms, which attracts the negatively charged PMS to approach and promotes the excitation of PMS, while the pyridine nitrogen can be used as an adsorption site to adsorb pollutants and enrich pollutants, which further shortens the attack distance from the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated in the catalytic center to the pollutants [31,32]. However, an efficient combination of metal species with CNTs still requires a deep exploration to solve with the stability of ultrafine metal species and electron transport between large metal nanoparticles and CNTs. Inspired by the above thoughts, we constructed surface polarized CNT twined oxygen-vacancy engineered cuprous oxide photothermal nanocomposite hybrids through triggering polydopamine incorporated Cu precursor modified CNT, and the highly defective carbon shell with surface-polarized properties due to the doped O/N species can be formed by high-temperature pyrolysis. These modified CNTs twined the generated Cu2O nanoparticles and endow the composites with abundant porous structure and oxygen vacancy sites, which benefits the mass transfer and PMS adsorption. The resulting catalysts were characterized to identify the physicochemical properties. The systematical catalytic performance was evaluated by leveraging the composite catalyst to activate PMS. Various contaminants adaptability study was implemented to identify the universal catalytic ability of this developed catalyst. The contribution of active species was explored through radical quenching experiments. In addition, using the Ca ions triggered cross-linking of sodium alginate, this catalyst was immobilized on a melamine sponge to obtain a bifunctional monolithic evaporator for wastewater treatment and solar-driven freshwater regeneration. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Methanol (99.9 %, CH3OH), Tert-butanol (99.5 %, C4H10O), L-histidine (99 %, C6H9N₃O₂), P-benzoquinone (98 %, C6H4O2), 3-Hydroxytyramine hydrochloride (C8H12ClNO2), Carbon nanotube (CNT), Copper acetate(Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O), ethanol (EtOH), Tris (hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (NH2C(CH2OH)3), Hydrochloric acid (HCl), Potassium peroxymonosulfate complex salt (PMS) and Bisphenol A (BPA, AR) were purchased from Energy Co. Ltd. Oxytetracycline (OTC, 98 %, C22H24N2O9), tetracycline (TC, CP, C22H24N2O8), norfloxacin (NFX, CP, C16H18FN3O3) and sodium alginate (SA, AR, (C6H7O6Na)n) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd chemicals. All the were used as received. The melamine sponge was purchased from Xianxu Insulation and Sound Insulation Building Materials Company. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst Before the experiment, 6.057 g of tris-hydroxyaminomethane was dissolved in 12 ml of hydrochloric acid solution at a concentration of 2 mol·L-1 and fixed to 1 L to obtain Tris–HCl buffer solution. 0.4828 g of dopamine hydrochloride was dissolved in 50 ml of Tris–HCl buffer solution at a concentration of 50 mmol·L-1, and then 0.5g of CNT was dispersed by ultrasonication for 10 min, stirred for 6 h, and then added to copper acetate solution (50 ml, 0.03 M), stirred for 12 h, collected by centrifugation and dried at 60 °C. The dried sample was calcined in a nitrogen atmosphere (600 °C, 2 h, 5 °C·min-1), and the final sample was named Cu-N/CNT30. By varying the concentration of copper acetate (0.02 M, 0.04 M, 0.05 M), a series of comparison samples (Cu-N/CNT20, Cu-N/CNT40, Cu-N/CNT50) can be obtained. 2.3 Characterizations The morphology and structure of the samples were determined using Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, S4800, Hitachi, Japan), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, JEM-2010 EX, JEOL, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ULVAC-PHI, Kanagawa, Japan) equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) was used to determine the elemental composition and chemical state of the samples. The C1s peak at 284.6 eV was used as the reference for binding energies. XRD results were performed using a Smartlab TM 9 KW (XPS, Rigaku Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a rotating anode and Cu Kα radiation (λ= 0.154178 nm). Open circuit voltage (OCP), linear scanning voltammetry (LSV), electrochemical impedance (EIS), and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were investigated on a CHI 760 E electrochemical workstation using a standard three-electrode method with a Pt electrode as the counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. The photothermal performance tests were performed using a UTi260B thermal imager (UNI-T, Yulide Technology, China) to record temperature variations and a daylight solar simulator (solar-500t, Beijing Newbit Technology, China) to provide simulated sunlight. 2.4 Catalytic performance assessment The catalytic performance of the catalysts was measured by evaluating the degradation rate of pollutants with PMS as an oxidizing agent. A certain amount of PMS was added to a BPA solution with an initial concentration of 0.2 g·L-1, and the initial concentration before adding the catalyst was recorded using an ultraviolet (UV) spectrophotometer (MAPADA P1800). Subsequently, the catalyst was dispersed in the BPA solution, followed by the addition of PMS solution at certain intervals, the BPA solution concentration was determined by separating the catalyst at certain intervals from the mixed solution using an aqueous filter membrane (0.45 µm) and subjected into detection of UV spectrophotometer. The reaction parameters were optimized by performing the control experiments with different concentrations of catalyst, PMS, and BPA. Degradation experiments of different pollutants (NFX\TC\OTC) were carried out according to the optimized reaction parameters, keeping other conditions constant. In addition, to explore the reaction mechanism of BPA degradation under optimal conditions, free radical quenching experiments were conducted using various radical quenching agents. The initial concentration was C0 (mg·L-1), the real-time concentration of the pollutant was Ct (mg·L-1), t (min) was taken as the reaction time, and the kinetic parameter was calculated as ln (Ct/C0) = -kt based on the reaction rate constant (k), and the pollutant degradation curves were obtained as a function of time to evaluate the degradation performance of the catalyst. 2.5 Integrated photothermal degradation and cleanwater regeneration To better determine the application potential of Cu-N/CNT in practical scenarios, a bifunctional floatable monolithic evaporator for sewage degradation and freshwater regeneration was constructed for experimental determination. 40 mg of Cu-N/CNT was dispersed in sodium alginate solution, and the above solution was dripped drop by drop onto a round melamine sponge with a diameter of 3.5 cm using a rubber-tipped burette, and then the sponge was immersed in CaCl2 solution for cross-linking, and the catalyst was fixed on the monolithic evaporator. Under simulated sunlight conditions, the integral evaporator was placed in the center of a beaker containing 50 ml of deionized water with a dust-free cloth, and the surface temperature of the sample was recorded every 10 min using an infrared thermal imager, and the mass change of the deionized water was recorded every 100 s using an electronic balance to calculate the photo-thermal conversion efficiency and the water evaporation rate of the integral evaporator. The deionized water was replaced with a solution of contaminants such as BPA, TC, NFX, OTC, etc., and the rate of water evaporation in the presence of the contaminants was determined in accordance with the above photothermal conditions. In addition, the degradation effect of the pollutants at 20 mg L-1 was determined using UV spectrophotometry under sunlight irradiation, and the device is recyclable and can be reused. 3 Results and discussion The synthetic approach of Cu-N/CNT is shown in Fig. 1 a, bird-nest-like surface-polarized CNT twined cuprous oxide nanoparticles can be constructed by coating polydopamine and copper species followed by high-temperature calcination under a nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting composites were endowed with improved surface polarity, abundant oxygen vacancy, and excellent photothermal properties. In particular, CNTs have an out-of-plane π-bonded and highly conjugated structure, which contributes to the reduction of the bandgap and also red-shifts the absorption wavelength, allowing for unique absorption in the near-infrared band [33], which affords excellent visible light absorption, broad absorption spectrum, and high stability. Moreover, CNT has good thermal conductivity, which can effectively absorb solar energy and transfer heat, and this characteristic can be utilized to use CNT as a photothermal material for photothermal conversion and later application in photothermal catalysis and freshwater regeneration [34,35]. Fig. 1(b, c) shows the representative TEM images of typical bird nest-like samples, the nanoparticles (∼100 nm) were twined with curving CNTs, wherein CNT was observed with a diameter of 12.8 nm and a thickness of 4.3 nm. The porous channel of CNTs can help the transport of contaminant molecules and trigger their local enrichment around the catalytic sites. In particular, these twined CNTs modified with N/O species can restrain the escaping of enriching contaminants, triggering an improved dynamical reaction process [36]. Fig. 1c showcases the High-resolution TEM image of Cu-N/CNT30, and the measured lattice spacing by FFT (Fig. 1e) corresponds to a lattice stripe of 0.301 nm in the (110) plane of Cu2O, confirming the successful introduction of Cu2O in the CNTs composites. To further identify the elemental composition and distribution of Cu-N/CNT30, we further analyzed the composite by EDX elemental mapping. Fig. 1f shows that C, N, and O elements were uniformly distributed in the catalyst. On the other hand, the aggregated Cu and O elements in the local region confirm the dominant oxidation state of copper species. Such observations demonstrate the special structure of the catalyst and specific composition state. Fig. 2 a shows the wide-angle XRD diffraction result of a series of comparative samples of Cu-N/CNT x (x=10, 20, 30, 50). All the samples showed a broad diffraction at 26.3°, attributed to the characteristic peak of the (002) crystal plane of CNT, affirming the existence of CNTs [37]. The diffraction peak at 36.4° was identified and corresponded to the (111) crystallographic plane of Cu2O, in agreement with the standard Cu2O (PDF#78–2076). Since increasing Cu loading in the sample, the intensity of the corresponding Cu2O diffraction becomes enlarged gradually. Despite the observation of big Cu2O nanoparticles, the small diffraction of nanoparticles indicates that the size of nanocrystals in the big particle is enough small, which benefits the catalytic reaction. To further determine the chemical environment and elemental composition of the Cu-N/CNT30 surface, we performed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis. Fig. 2b verifies the main elemental compositions of C, N, O, and Cu of the sample. According to the precise deconvolution result of various elements (Fig. 2c), it can be seen that the high-resolution C 1s was deconvolved into three binding energy peaks at 283.3 eV, 284.8 eV, and 290 eV, corresponding to C-C, C-N/O, and C=C, respectively. Among them, the presence of C-N/O bonds indicates successful doping with N or O species, which would improve the surface polarity of CNTs [38–41]. The high-resolution spectrum of N 1s in Fig. 2d demonstrates individual peaks for pyridine N (398.3 eV), pyrrole N (400.0 eV), and graphite N (404.7 eV). The two active N species, pyrrole N and pyridine N, in the samples, often contribute to the improved adsorption performance of the samples for contaminants [42]. The lone pair of electrons possessed by pyridine N can enhance the charge density of the sample, which is favorable for electron transfer during degradation and can also be used as an active site to activate PMS and increase the degradation rate [43,44]. From the high-resolution spectra of Cu 2p in Fig. 2e, it can be seen that the deconvolution peaks at 953.0 eV and 935.0 eV can be attributed to little fraction of Cu2+ in Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, respectively, while the deconvolution peaks at 952.0 eV and 932.5 eV were observed to occupied the dominant role, which can be attributed to Cu+ in Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, respectively, which confirms the state of cuprous oxides species in Cu-N/CNTs [45]. On the other hand, the O 1s spectrum was provided and deconvoluted into three core levels, corresponding to lattice oxygen, oxygen vacancy, and surface adsorption oxygen. In particular, the high fraction of oxygen vacancy accounts for the more surface trapping sites for PMS molecules, which improves the activation of PMS toward active species [46]. The successful introduction of nitrogen doping and cuprous oxide in the modified carbon nanotubes was confirmed in Fig. S1 and Table S1 to be essential for improving the catalytic degradation performance of the catalysts. To further understand the electron transfer ability of the catalyst, several key electrochemical characterizations were performed such as Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS, Fig. 3 a), Linear Sweep Voltammetry (LSV, Fig. 3b) curves, and Open-circuit voltage test (OCV, Fig. 3c). In the EIS spectra (Fig. 3a), the semicircle diameter at high-frequency region is related to the charge transfer resistance (CTR). A smaller semicircle of Cu-incorporated CNTs implies a lower CTR, indicating more facile electron transfer at the electrode-electrolyte interface compared to the pure CNTs. This indicates that the construction of special N/O co-modified CNT twined oxygen-vacancy engineered cuprous oxide releases a superior ability to promote charge transfer, which is beneficial for redox reactions. This could be due to its unique surface properties or chemical composition that provides more active sites for electron exchange [47,48]. As electron-rich sites, oxygen vacancies can capture electrons and reduce the charge transfer energy barrier. Their high proportion provides more sites for electron transfer. The excellent electrical conductivity of carbon nanotubes and their close connection with cuprous oxide provide a pathway for electron transport, and the N/O co-modification further enhances the interaction between the two. In fact, the decrease in charge transfer resistance mainly stems from the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and the interaction between carbon nanotubes and cuprous oxide. LSV curves (Fig. 3b) show the onset potential and the current density in the potential range providing valuable insights. Cu-N/CNT30 exhibits a lower onset potential, meaning easier electron loss from the catalyst to trigger reaction occurrence. It demonstrates a higher catalytic activity in the initial stage [49,50]. The OCV test showcases some key information for electron transfer, especially for the PMS-containing solution. The addition of PMS in the process induces the potential variation at the specific time, in particular, the curve of Cu-N/CNT30 changes to a greater extent when introducing the PMS molecule, which indicates that the electron transfer occurrence between PMS and catalyst, wherein the big potential variation accounts for the more electron transfer and stronger PMS activation process. Apart from the above properties, the photothermal conversion ability was further explored. As shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S2, the photothermal images of Cu-N/CNT30 wet membrane on the air-laid paper dipping in DI water, TC, BPA, and NFX solution were collected at different times. The obvious temperature variation of the Cu-N/CNT30 wet membrane under the irradiation of one sunlight can be identified, and the surface temperature can enhanced to beyond 40 °C, indicating the excellent photothermal conversion ability of the catalyst [51–53]. Note that the different contaminants containing solution make the temperature variation different, which possibly results from the adsorption of large contaminant molecules on the catalyst affecting the photothermal conversion properties. According to the time-dependent temperature variation curves (Fig. 4e), the temperature rise is drastic at the initial 10 min, the temperature can reach ∼35 °C, the temperature rise becomes slow after 10 min, and reach 40 °C at the end of the irradiation. This result indicates the catalyst affords excellent photothermal conversion performance, which can be applied for later photothermal catalysis and solar-driven interfacial water evaporation. To investigate the catalytic performance of Cu-N/CNTx series catalysts, the degradation performance curves of different catalysts for the target pollutant BPA under PMS were determined. Fig. 5 a shows the degradation curves of Cu-N/CNT series catalysts on BPA. Note that the untreated CNTs can also reduce the concentration of pollutants in water because their exposed surface can adsorb organic pollutants. At the same time, their good electron conduction performance promotes electron transfer to participate in redox reactions, and the presence of defects or functional groups on the surface can act as catalytic active sites to participate in the reaction triggering the PMS activation and degradation. The BPA degradation efficiency of CNTs increased significantly after loading metal Cu, confirming that the introduction of metal Cu improved the degradation performance of the catalysts. According to Fig. 5b, the order of the reaction kinetic constants of the five catalysts was Cu-N/CNT40 (0.52 min-1) > Cu-N/CNT30 (0.47 min-1) > Cu-N/CNT20 (0.34 min-1) > CNT (0.10 min-1). Among them, both Cu-N/CNT30 and Cu-N/CNT40 were able to degrade BPA completely within 10 min, and their reaction kinetic constants were comparable, in the principle of environmental protection and conservation, Cu-N/CNT30, with a lower concentration of Cu ions, was finally selected as the optimal catalyst. Fig. 5(c-f) shows the spectra of triple-D fluorescence of BPA degradation in the presence of the optimal Cu-N/CNT30 under the action of PMS, and it can be seen that the color of the central ring at the wavelength of 200–400 nm representing contaminants slowly becomes lighter with prolonged time, indicating that the concentration of BPA in the solution gradually decreases, which proves that the catalyst has excellent degradation performance [54]. To further investigate the optimal conditions for the application of the Cu-N/CNT30/PMS system, the effects of the reaction parameters on the BPA degradation experiments were investigated based on the control of PMS dosage, the catalyst dosage, the BPA concentration, and the temperature as variables. Fig. 6 (a, b) shows the BPA degradation curves and the fitted reaction kinetics curves by changing the PMS dosage only. With the increment of the PMS dosage, the active centers of the reaction increased and the degradation rate was accelerated, and the BPA could be degraded completely in about 5 min. Excessive amount of PMS may be over-adsorbed on the catalyst, which may inhibit the activation by weakening the activation effect, therefore, the most appropriate dosage of PMS was selected as 0.2 g·L-1. The results showed that the PMS dosage of 0.2 g·L-1 was suitable for the degradation of BPA [43]. Fig. 6(c, d) shows that when other conditions remained unchanged and only the catalyst dosage was changed, increasing the amount of catalyst resulted in more active sites in contact with pollutants and a significant increase in the reaction rate, but the increase in the catalyst dosage from 0.2 to 0.3 g·L-1, and the increase in the catalyst dosage from 0.1 to 0.2 g·L-1, did not increase the reaction rate much, which indicated that the excess catalyst was not very useful in the enhancement of the degradation rate. This indicates that the excess catalyst is not useful for the enhancement of the degradation rate. For the consideration of material cost, 0.2 g·L-1 of catalyst was chosen as the optimum condition. For the consideration of material cost, 0.2 g·L-1 of catalyst was chosen as the optimum condition. Fig. 6(e, f) shows that the catalytic degradation performance decreases with the increase of pollutant BPA concentration, and the catalyst and PMS can play a better role at low BPA concentration. The effect of temperature on the degradation performance was investigated in Fig. 6(g-i), the degradation rate was accelerated with the increase in temperature, and the kinetic constants of the reaction were in accordance with this characteristic: 50 °C (0.909 min-1) > 40 °C (0.862 min-1) > 30 °C (0.838 min-1). The activation energy Ea = 9.378 kJ mol-1 is calculated using the Arrhenius equation. In the reaction of degrading BPA by activating PMS with a catalyst, this value has obvious advantages. At the same temperature, it can increase the reaction rate constant, accelerate the reaction rate, improve the treatment efficiency in wastewater treatment, and at the same time reduce the temperature requirements of the reaction, save energy, and facilitate the application and promotion of industrial-scale wastewater treatment processes. To investigate the ROS in the degradation of BPA by Cu-N/CNT30, we added four kinds of quenching agents, namely, methanol (MeOH), tert-butanol (TBA), histidine (L-his), and p-benzoquinone (p-BQ), and searched for the ROS that play a major role in degradation through the effect of the bursts. MeOH can quench both the ·OH and ·SO4 - radicals and TBA is mainly used to quench ·OH. The L-his and p-BQ can be used as ·O2 - and 1O2 quenching agents, respectively [55]. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the quenching effects were reduced to different degrees after the addition of the bursting agents, but the bursting effects of MeOH and TBA were very weak, in contrast to that of L-his and p-BQ, which were very obvious. The results of Fig. S3 and Fig. 7b show that after adding MeOH, TBA, L-his and p-BQ, the kinetic constant of the reaction decreased from 0.839 min-1 to 0.815 min-1, 0.777 min-1, 0.086 min-1 and 0.081 min-1 respectively, indicating that the effects of ·OH and ·SO4 - on the degradation process were very weak, whereas ·O2 - and 1O2 were the main ROS. This indicates that longer-activity-life ·O2 - and 1O2 can be generated in this system, which is beneficial for the unremitting pollutant degradation. To test the effect of inorganic anions in the environment on the catalytic degradation of BPA, the degradation effect of Cu-N/CNT30 was examined by adding different inorganic anions. Fig. 7c shows the experimental results after adding different anions under the optimal experimental conditions. The results show that the inhibition of BPA degradation by the studied anions is CO3 2- > HCO3 - > H2PO4 - >Cl- > SO4 -. Among them, Cl- and SO4 2- in a neutral environment did not interfere, while the addition of H2PO4 -, HCO3 -, and CO3 2- weakened the catalytic degradation performance of BPA. This is because HCO3 - and CO3 2- are reducible. They consume active species, adsorb on the catalyst surface, change the charge distribution and microenvironment of the active center, and compete with pollutants for active sites. The presence of H2PO4 - can interfere with the proton transfer process, thus inhibiting the effective activation of PMS and further exerting a certain inhibitory effect on the reaction. Cl-, on the other hand, is stable in the system, not easily oxidized or reduced, weakly binds to the active center of the catalyst, and does not impede the reaction. SO4 - is components or products of PMS. They do not interfere with the activation of PMS and the generation of active species, nor do they cause side reactions with pollutants or active species [56,57]. A variety of antibiotics have been widely used, but overuse and improper handling of antibiotics have caused antibiotics to accumulate in water, with harmful effects on the environment and the human body [57–59]. Therefore, to verify that the Cu-N/CNT/PMS system has an appreciable degradation performance for both BPA and antibiotics produced from degraded plastics, therefore, antibiotic degradation experiments were conducted. The results in Fig. 7d show that Cu-N/CNT30 exhibits high catalytic activity in the oxidative degradation of tetracycline and oxytetracycline, which are degraded completely at 3 min, however, the catalytic activity exhibited in the application to norfloxacin is relatively weak. During the oxidation process, organic macromolecules are broken down into small molecules, but these small molecules have the potential to be toxic or even larger, so the TOC of the process of degrading organic matter was measured to determine the effect of mineralization of organic matter [60]. Fig. 7(e, f) shows that TOC removal in NFX was the hardest compared to other organic pollutants. For the 60 min degradation process, the TOC removal rates were 61.0% (BPA) > 47.7% (TC) > 39.9% (NFX) for the single pollutant TOC removal determination, respectively. And it can be visualized that the TOC removal rate of mixed pollutants is even higher than that of single pollutants, which is advantageous in the practical application of mixed pollutant water treatment, and the TOC removal rates of mixed pollutants were 86.7% (BPA&TC)>79.4% (BPA&TC&NFX) > 78.8% (BPA&NFX) > 57.0% (TC&NFX). Taken together, Cu-N/CNT30 shows good potential for application in the field of catalytic degradation of organic pollutants. To explore the practical application potential of Cu-N-CNT30, the water treatment as well as the recycling performance of the catalyst in tap water and lake water were tested. Relative to the degradation process in the BPA solution in Fig. 7g and Fig. S4, BPA can also be degraded completely in tap water in about 5 min, but the lake water has more impurities, which will make the removal of BPA more difficult. There are natural organic substances in lake water, such as humic acid, fulvic acid, etc. These organic substances possess certain reducibility and reactivity. They will compete with the target organic pollutants for active species and consume free radicals. In addition, these natural organic substances may also adsorb on the surface of the catalyst, block the active sites, or change the surface properties of the catalyst, thus affecting the adsorption and degradation of organic pollutants by the catalyst. The stability of Cu-N/CNT30 was examined by the catalytic degradation cycle experiment of BPA (Fig. 7h). At the end of each experiment, the active sites and pores on the catalyst surface would be blocked by undegraded pollutants and degradation intermediates, which made the adsorption of PMS on the catalyst surface somewhat reduced and slowed down the electron transfer, resulting in a decrease in the activity of Cu-N/CNT catalyst. The performance of the catalyst decreased slightly after cycling, which could be attributed to the high carbon content in the catalyst and the partial loss of activity of the metal active sites after the reaction, but the catalyst still showed high activity after several cycles [61]. The results showed that the catalyst is recyclable in practical applications. The degradation of BPA by different catalysts under the most use of PMS is reported in Fig. 7i and Table S2 [62–67]. In environmental management, some pollutants are difficult to remove together by a single method, so freshwater reclamation from wastewater is also critical [68]. Solar-driven evaporation of interfacial water has received much attention in recent years for freshwater reclamation. This method removes heavy metals, microorganisms, and most organic pollutants from water and yields clean distilled water, which is one of the effective solutions to water scarcity [69]. Carbon-based materials with excellent photothermal conversion properties and chemical stability stand out among photothermal materials [70]. Therefore, the construction of composite materials with dual functions of degrading wastewater and regenerating fresh water can provide effective solutions to wastewater treatment problems and desalination problems. Increasing water scarcity and pollution pose a great challenge to human society, and the search for suitable freshwater regeneration methods is imminent. In recent years, interfacial solar water evaporation has attracted much attention for its low dependence on infrastructure and energy efficiency [71]. Solar-driven interfacial water evaporation is a viable technology for freshwater reclamation by utilizing photothermal materials placed at the water-air interface to drive solar energy into thermal energy, and by limiting the conversion of solar energy to thermal energy at the top of the target body of water, which greatly reduces heat loss [72]. Fig. 8 (a, b) shows the initial sponge support and monolithic evaporator made of Cu-N/CNT30 immobilized in a melamine sponge using a hydrogel crosslinked with sodium alginate and CaCl2, which was measured to be 3.4 cm in diameter. Fig. 8(c, d, e) exhibits the experimental setup diagram and details of water evaporation and degradation under simulated sunlight. Fig. 8(f, g, h) showcases the SEM images of sponge framework, the monolithic evaporator made from hydrogel modified blank sponge, and catalyst and hydrogel modified evaporator. The change in water body mass was recorded at 100 s intervals during the 60 min water evaporation using an electronic balance. Fig. 8i records the rate of water evaporation during 60 min, which was 1.86 kg·m-2·h-1 in BPA solution, 1.85 kg·m-2·h-1 in NFX solution, and 1.89 kg·m-2·h-1 in TC solution. In deionized water, the rate of water evaporation was up to 1.62 kg·m-2·h-1, and the efficiency of the photo-thermal conversion was as high as 88.30%. The catalytic degradation performance of BPA (Fig. 8j) shows that the catalyst could degrade about 93% of BPA within 1 h. This demonstrated the successful application of the integral evaporator of the catalyst Cu-N/CNT30 for wastewater degradation and freshwater regeneration, and the catalyst was integrated on a sponge with excellent recoverability has a significant advantage in the practical application of water treatment [73,74]. Specifically, the four reaction cycles for BPA using a monolith evaporator show consistent degradation efficiency, further indicating the huge potential in the stable practical application. In addition, comparing Cu-N/CNT30 with other reported photothermal materials according to Fig. S5 and Table S3, the results show that the catalyst has significant advantages in both water evaporation rate and photothermal conversion efficiency [75–80]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a photothermal hybrid composed of surface-polarized CNTs twined oxygen-vacancy engineered cuprous oxide (Cu-N/CNT30) was successfully constructed. Its special nest-like structural characteristics were confirmed by various characterization methods. Impressively, the abundant oxygen vacancy sites can be formed in the cuprous oxides, which is beneficial to the trapping effect of PMS, evidenced by the open circuit voltage test. The surface polarity of CNTs due to the N/O co-doping effect can trigger improved enrichment of polar contaminants, which would shorten the diffusion of ROS toward the contaminants and improve the lifespan. In addition, this catalyst was endowed with excellent photothermal conversion ability. In terms of catalytic degradation of pollutants, the introduction of copper onto the CNT improved the catalytic PMS activation compared to untreated CNTs. The optimal catalystCu-N/CNT30 showcased the excellent catalytic degradation of BPA with the reaction rate constant reaching 0.47 min-1, and the activation energy is 9.38 kJ·mol-1. The reaction mechanism demonstrated the dominant role of ·O2 - and 1O2 for pollutant degradation. Besides, the optimal catalyst also showed great flexibility for a variety of antibiotics, and the TOC removal rate (78.8%) of mixed pollutants was demonstrated to be higher than a single one. The great degradation performance of pollutants in tap water can be attained. The monolithic evaporator fabricated performs well in pollutant degradation and clean water regeneration, providing an effective way for wastewater treatment and freshwater regeneration. coredata.dc:description: Photothermal hybrids composed of nanocarbon and metal species are promising in solar-driven photothermal conversion and later application of water purification. Herein, the photothermal hybrid with surface-polarized carbon nanotube (CNT) twined oxygen vacancy-engineered cuprous oxides was constructed. The surface polar oxygen and nitrogen moieties were introduced onto the CNT, enriching the surface polarity of the nanocarbon, which further twined the in-situ generated oxygen vacancy-engineered cuprous oxides. The constructed catalyst was endowed with abundant Cu(I) reactive sites and oxygen vacancy, providing the efficient trapping effect and enough exposed active sites to trigger improved peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation. In addition, the obtained catalyst affords superior photothermal conversion efficiency, thereby showcasing the great potential in solar-driven water purification. Therefore, the catalyst shows excellent bisphenol A (BPA) degradation performance with a reaction rate constant of 0.47 min-1, and activation energy (Ea=9.38 kJ·mol-1).. The reaction mechanism study indicates the main contribution of singlet oxygen and superoxide radicals in the BPA degradation. More importantly, the obtained catalyst affords the excellent total organic carbon (TOC) removal ability for mixed contaminants, higher than that of single contaminant removal, which shows great potential for practical complicated wastewater purification. Finally, the obtained photothermal hybrids were anchored onto the tailored sponge through a hydrogel tethering strategy, which acts as a monolith evaporator to enable cleanwater regeneration and contaminant degradation.
